title: Security Policies and Procedures
description: Develop comprehensive security policies, standards, and procedures. Create acceptable use policies, incident response plans, change management processes, and security awareness training programs to establish organizational security governance.

# SECURITY POLICIES & PROCEDURES EXERCISE
# Establish security governance framework

## SCENARIO: TechCorp Security Program
## - Organization: 500 employees, multiple locations
## - Current state: Minimal security policies
## - Challenge: Develop comprehensive security program
## - Goal: Establish policies, procedures, and awareness

## PART 1: POLICY HIERARCHY & FRAMEWORK
## Q1: Policy vs Standard vs Procedure:
##     Policy: _______ (high-level management intent)
##     - Example: "All users must use strong passwords"
##     - Mandatory: Yes
##     - Enforcement: Required
##     
##     Standard: _______ (specific technical requirements)
##     - Example: "Minimum 12 characters, uppercase, number, symbol"
##     - Mandatory: Yes
##     - Measurable: Specific criteria
##     
##     Procedure: _______ (step-by-step implementation)
##     - Example: "1. Go to Settings, 2. Click Password, 3. Enter new..."
##     - Mandatory: Yes (for employees)
##     - Detailed: Implementation instructions
##     
##     Guideline: _______ (recommended best practice)
##     - Example: "Consider 3-month password rotation"
##     - Mandatory: No (recommendation)
##     - Flexible: Organization can choose

## Q2: Policy hierarchy structure:
##     Level 1: _______ (broad, organizational level)
##     - Example: "Information Security Policy"
##     - Scope: Entire organization
##     - Approval: CEO/Board
##     - Frequency change: Rarely (1-2 years)
##     
##     Level 2: _______ (domain-specific policies)
##     - Examples: Access Control, Data Protection, Incident Response
##     - Scope: Specific business area
##     - Approval: Security Committee
##     - Frequency change: Annually
##     
##     Level 3: _______ (implementation details)
##     - Examples: Password standards, firewall rules, backup procedures
##     - Scope: Specific technology or process
##     - Approval: Department/Team lead
##     - Frequency change: As needed (quarterly, monthly)

## Q3: Policy audience identification:
##     Question: "Who needs to follow this policy?"
##     
##     Organization-wide policies:
##     - Audience: _______ (all employees)
##     - Example: Acceptable Use Policy (email, internet, phones)
##     - Enforcement: Everyone (no exceptions)
##     
##     Department policies:
##     - Audience: _______ (specific department)
##     - Example: Finance Department Data Classification
##     - Enforcement: Department members
##     
##     IT staff policies:
##     - Audience: _______ (IT personnel only)
##     - Example: Privileged Access Management (PAM)
##     - Enforcement: IT staff
##     
##     Contractor policies:
##     - Audience: _______ (vendors, consultants)
##     - Example: Vendor Security Requirements
##     - Enforcement: Third parties

## PART 2: ACCEPTABLE USE POLICY (AUP)
## Q4: Purpose of Acceptable Use Policy:
##     Why create AUP?
##     - Define: _______ (allowed vs prohibited use)
##     - Protect: Company assets and reputation
##     - Legal: Document expectations for users
##     - Enforcement: Basis for discipline
##     
##     Example language:
##     "Employees may use email for business purposes.
##      Personal use is limited to incidental (minimal).
##      Prohibited: Adult content, hacking, espionage."

## Q5: Key AUP components:
##     Covered resources:
##     - _______ (company-provided devices)
##     - Company networks (WiFi, LAN, VPN)
##     - Email systems
##     - Internet/web access
##     - Cloud services
##     - Voicemail and phones
##     
##     Prohibited activities: _______ (list examples)
##     - Accessing restricted data without authorization
##     - Installing unauthorized software
##     - Hacking, reverse engineering
##     - Violating intellectual property
##     - Harassment, hate speech
##     - Adult content, illegal material
##     - Sending spam or phishing
##     - Bypassing security controls
##     
##     Permitted activities:
##     - Business-related work
##     - Email, web, cloud (approved services)
##     - Incidental personal use (defined limit)
##     - Reporting security issues

## Q6: Personal use allowances:
##     Question: "Can employees use company email personally?"
##     
##     Strict policy:
##     - Personal use: _______ (none, business only)
##     - Rationale: Minimize distractions, simplify auditing
##     - Enforcement: Easy (clear boundary)
##     - Disadvantage: Rigid, may reduce morale
##     
##     Permissive policy:
##     - Personal use: _______ (incidental, minimal)
##     - Limit: "Reasonable personal use" (undefined)
##     - Rationale: Flexible, improves morale
##     - Problem: Vague, hard to enforce
##     
##     Best practice: _______ (define "incidental")
##     - Definition: <10% of usage or <1 hour/day
##     - Examples: Personal emails, news, personal finance
##     - Still prohibited: Retail, personal business
##     - Monitoring: Random audits to verify compliance

## Q7: Consequences of AUP violation:
##     Progressive discipline:
##     - 1st offense (minor): _______ (warning, documentation)
##     - 2nd offense: _______ (written warning, restricted access)
##     - 3rd offense: _______ (suspension or termination)
##     - Severe violations: _______ (immediate termination, legal action)
##     
##     Examples of escalation:
##     - Accessing colleague's email: Warning
##     - Repeated after warning: Suspension
##     - Stealing trade secrets: Termination + legal
##     - Hacking systems: Police involved

## PART 3: INCIDENT RESPONSE PROCEDURES
## Q8: Incident response phases:
##     Phase 1: _______ (Detection, analysis, triage)
##     - Who detects: IDS alert, user report, log analysis
##     - Action: Verify incident occurred
##     - Example: "Unusual login from foreign IP detected"
##     
##     Phase 2: _______ (Investigate, stop attack)
##     - Containment: Isolate affected system
##     - Example: Unplug compromised server
##     - Investigation: Gather evidence
##     - Example: Review logs, take memory dump
##     
##     Phase 3: _______ (Remove malware, restore systems)
##     - Eradicate: Remove attacker (patches, clean OS)
##     - Recover: Restore from clean backup
##     - Verify: Confirm systems operational
##     
##     Phase 4: _______ (Lessons learned, improve controls)
##     - Timeline: 1-2 weeks after incident
##     - Activity: Root cause analysis
##     - Output: Recommendations, updated procedures

## Q9: Incident severity classifications:
##     Critical (CVSS 9-10):
##     - Definition: _______ (severe impact, urgent response)
##     - Examples: Data breach (100+ records), ransomware, network down
##     - Response time: _______ (immediate, <1 hour)
##     - Team: All hands, skip meeting protocol
##     - Escalation: CEO notified
##     
##     High (CVSS 7-8):
##     - Definition: _______ (significant impact, quick response)
##     - Examples: Malware on 10+ computers, DDoS attack
##     - Response time: _______ (<4 hours)
##     - Team: Security + IT
##     - Escalation: Management notified
##     
##     Medium (CVSS 4-6):
##     - Definition: _______ (moderate impact)
##     - Examples: Single compromised account, phishing campaign
##     - Response time: _______ (<24 hours)
##     - Team: Security department
##     - Escalation: Supervisor notified
##     
##     Low (CVSS 0-3):
##     - Definition: _______ (minimal impact)
##     - Examples: Failed login attempts, suspicious file deleted
##     - Response time: _______ (<1 week)
##     - Team: Junior analyst
##     - Escalation: Documented only

## Q10: Communication during incident:
##      Incident response communication:
##      - External: _______ (when, what to say)
##      - Legal: Regulatory reporting requirements
##      - Customer: Transparency
##      - Media: Control narrative
##      
##      Example:
##      "We detected unauthorized access to 500 customer records.
##       Investigation ongoing. Password reset recommended.
##       Regulatory notification: 72 hours (GDPR)."

## PART 4: CHANGE MANAGEMENT
## Q11: Change management process:
##      Steps:
##      1. Request: _______ (document change needed)
##      2. Assessment: _______ (analyze impact, risk)
##      3. Approval: _______ (management/security review)
##      4. Planning: _______ (implementation plan, testing)
##      5. Implementation: _______ (deploy, monitor)
##      6. Verification: _______ (confirm success)
##      7. Documentation: _______ (record change)

## Q12: Types of changes:
##      Standard change:
##      - Definition: _______ (low-risk, routine change)
##      - Example: Windows security update, firmware patch
##      - Approval: _______ (IT lead can approve)
##      - Testing: Minimal (already tested)
##      - Rollback: Simple (restore previous version)
##      
##      Significant change:
##      - Definition: _______ (moderate-risk, impacts production)
##      - Example: New firewall rule, database migration
##      - Approval: _______ (security committee required)
##      - Testing: Required (test environment first)
##      - Rollback: Plan needed
##      
##      Emergency change:
##      - Definition: _______ (critical issue, must fix now)
##      - Example: Network outage, ransomware attack
##      - Approval: _______ (Incident commander approves)
##      - Testing: Minimal (fix first, test later)
##      - Documentation: After the fact

## Q13: Change scheduling:
##      Maintenance window:
##      - Definition: _______ (designated time for changes)
##      - Typical: Sunday 2-6 AM (low traffic)
##      - Notification: 2 weeks advance notice
##      - Backup: Before change made
##      - Testing: Before deployment
##      
##      Change freezes:
##      - When: _______ (holidays, year-end, critical period)
##      - Dates: Example: Dec 20 - Jan 2
##      - Exceptions: Emergency fixes only
##      - Reason: Minimize risk during busy times
##      - Benefits: Reduce incidents, easier support

## PART 5: SECURITY AWARENESS & TRAINING
## Q14: Security awareness program:
##      Purpose: _______ (educate employees on security)
##      - Build: Security culture
##      - Reduce: Human error (phishing, weak passwords)
##      - Comply: Regulatory requirements (HIPAA, PCI-DSS)
##      - Measure: Employee knowledge and behavior
##      
##      Components:
##      - Onboarding: New employee training
##      - Annual: Refresher training (mandatory)
##      - Targeted: Role-specific (admin, finance)
##      - Testing: Simulated phishing
##      - Recognition: Reward security champions

## Q15: Training content topics:
##      Required for all:
##      - _______ (password management, strong passwords)
##      - Phishing awareness (recognize attacks)
##      - Social engineering (manipulation tactics)
##      - Clean desk (classify documents properly)
##      - Data handling (protect sensitive data)
##      - Incident reporting (what to do if compromise)
##      
##      Role-specific:
##      - IT admins: _______ (privileged access, logging)
##      - Finance: Payment fraud, wire transfer schemes
##      - HR: Background checks, confidentiality
##      - Executives: Business email compromise

## Q16: Measuring training effectiveness:
##      Metrics:
##      - Completion: _______ (% of employees trained)
##      - Assessment: _______ (test scores)
##      - Phishing rate: _______ (% who click phishing links)
##      - Incident reduction: _______ (fewer incidents after training)
##      
##      Example:
##      - Baseline: 15% click phishing email
##      - After training: 5% click rate
##      - Success: 66% reduction in phishing clicks

## PART 6: COMPLIANCE & DOCUMENTATION
## Q17: Policy documentation requirements:
##      Every policy must include:
##      - Purpose: _______ (why this policy exists)
##      - Scope: _______ (who it applies to)
##      - Owner: _______ (who maintains policy)
##      - Review date: _______ (when next reviewed)
##      - Approval: _______ (who approved it)
##      - Effective date: _______ (when it starts)
##      - Version: _______ (track changes)
##      
##      Storage: _______ (accessible, searchable)
##      - Location: Policy management system
##      - Access: All employees can view
##      - Sign-off: Users acknowledge they read

## Q18: Regulatory compliance mapping:
##      Scenario: TechCorp handles customer payment data (PCI-DSS)
##      
##      Requirements:
##      - PCI-DSS #1: _______ (Firewall, network segmentation)
##      - PCI-DSS #2: Remove defaults
##      - PCI-DSS #3: _______ (Protect stored card data)
##      - PCI-DSS #4: Encrypt data in transit
##      - PCI-DSS #5: Antivirus/antimalware
##      - PCI-DSS #6: Security patching
##      - PCI-DSS #7: _______ (Access control, least privilege)
##      - PCI-DSS #8: User authentication, MFA
##      
##      Mapping:
##      - Policy: Access Control Policy
##      - Links to: PCI-DSS #1, #7 (network access)
##      - Implementation: Firewall rules document

## Q19: Audit and enforcement:
##      Audit types:
##      - Compliance: _______ (Are we following policies?)
##      - Effectiveness: _______ (Are policies working?)
##      - Regular: _______ (scheduled, routine)
##      - Surprise: _______ (random, unannounced)
##      
##      Audit findings:
##      - Non-compliance: _______ (not following policy)
##      - Gap: Missing control or procedure
##      - Action: Remediation required
##      - Timeline: 30-90 days to fix
##      - Follow-up: Verify correction

## Q20: Policy review and update:
##      When to review:
##      - Scheduled: _______ (annually, every 2 years)
##      - Event-triggered: _______ (after incident, regulation change)
##      - Technology: New tools or systems
##      - Examples: New cloud service, remote work, AI
##      
##      Review process:
##      - Owner: Policy author
##      - Stakeholders: Users affected, IT, Security
##      - Update: Reflect current state
##      - Approval: Management sign-off
##      - Communication: Announce changes
##      
##      Change log: _______ (track versions)
##      - Version 1.0: Initial policy
##      - Version 1.1: Updated MFA requirements
##      - Version 1.2: Added cloud services
##      - Version 2.0: Major revision (remote work)

# SECURITY POLICIES & PROCEDURES SOLUTION

## PART 1: POLICY HIERARCHY & FRAMEWORK

### Policy vs Standard vs Procedure

**Policy**: **HIGH-LEVEL MANAGEMENT INTENT** âœ“
- Example: "All users must use strong passwords"
- Mandatory: Yes
- Enforcement: Required
- Purpose: Set organizational direction

**Standard**: **SPECIFIC TECHNICAL REQUIREMENTS** âœ“
- Example: "Minimum 12 characters, uppercase, number, symbol"
- Mandatory: Yes
- Measurable: Specific criteria
- Purpose: Define compliance requirements

**Procedure**: **STEP-BY-STEP IMPLEMENTATION** âœ“
- Example: "1. Go to Settings, 2. Click Password, 3. Enter new..."
- Mandatory: Yes (for employees)
- Detailed: Implementation instructions
- Purpose: Enable consistent execution

**Guideline**: **RECOMMENDED BEST PRACTICE** âœ“
- Example: "Consider 3-month password rotation"
- Mandatory: No (recommendation)
- Flexible: Organization can choose
- Purpose: Provide recommended approaches

### Policy Hierarchy Structure

**Level 1**: **BROAD, ORGANIZATIONAL LEVEL** âœ“
- Example: "Information Security Policy"
- Scope: Entire organization
- Approval: CEO/Board
- Frequency change: Rarely (1-2 years)
- Purpose: Set organizational tone

**Level 2**: **DOMAIN-SPECIFIC POLICIES** âœ“
- Examples: Access Control, Data Protection, Incident Response
- Scope: Specific business area
- Approval: Security Committee
- Frequency change: Annually
- Purpose: Address specific domains

**Level 3**: **IMPLEMENTATION DETAILS** âœ“
- Examples: Password standards, firewall rules, backup procedures
- Scope: Specific technology or process
- Approval: Department/Team lead
- Frequency change: As needed (quarterly, monthly)
- Purpose: Enable consistent deployment

### Policy Audience Identification

**Organization-wide policies**:
- Audience: **ALL EMPLOYEES** âœ“
- Example: Acceptable Use Policy (email, internet, phones)
- Enforcement: Everyone (no exceptions)

**Department policies**:
- Audience: **SPECIFIC DEPARTMENT** âœ“
- Example: Finance Department Data Classification
- Enforcement: Department members

**IT staff policies**:
- Audience: **IT PERSONNEL ONLY** âœ“
- Example: Privileged Access Management (PAM)
- Enforcement: IT staff

**Contractor policies**:
- Audience: **VENDORS, CONSULTANTS** âœ“
- Example: Vendor Security Requirements
- Enforcement: Third parties (contractual)

## PART 2: ACCEPTABLE USE POLICY (AUP)

### Purpose of Acceptable Use Policy

**Why create AUP?**
- Define: **ALLOWED VS PROHIBITED USE** âœ“
- Protect: Company assets and reputation
- Legal: Document expectations for users
- Enforcement: Basis for discipline
- Defense: Legal protection if terminating for violation

**Example language**:
"Employees may use email for business purposes.
Personal use is limited to incidental (minimal).
Prohibited: Adult content, hacking, espionage."

### Key AUP Components

**Covered resources**:
- **COMPANY-PROVIDED DEVICES** âœ“
- Company networks (WiFi, LAN, VPN)
- Email systems
- Internet/web access
- Cloud services
- Voicemail and phones

**Prohibited activities**: **LIST EXAMPLES** âœ“
- Accessing restricted data without authorization
- Installing unauthorized software
- Hacking, reverse engineering
- Violating intellectual property
- Harassment, hate speech
- Adult content, illegal material
- Sending spam or phishing
- Bypassing security controls

**Permitted activities**:
- Business-related work
- Email, web, cloud (approved services)
- Incidental personal use (defined limit)
- Reporting security issues (encouraged)

### Personal Use Allowances

**Strict policy**:
- Personal use: **NONE, BUSINESS ONLY**
- Rationale: Minimize distractions, simplify auditing
- Enforcement: Easy (clear boundary)
- Disadvantage: Rigid, may reduce morale

**Permissive policy**:
- Personal use: **INCIDENTAL, MINIMAL**
- Limit: "Reasonable personal use" (undefined)
- Rationale: Flexible, improves morale
- Problem: Vague, hard to enforce

**Best practice**: **DEFINE "INCIDENTAL"** âœ“
- Definition: <10% of usage or <1 hour/day
- Examples: Personal emails, news, personal finance
- Still prohibited: Retail, personal business
- Monitoring: Random audits to verify compliance

### Consequences of AUP Violation

**Progressive discipline**:
- 1st offense (minor): **WARNING, DOCUMENTATION** âœ“
- 2nd offense: **WRITTEN WARNING, RESTRICTED ACCESS** âœ“
- 3rd offense: **SUSPENSION OR TERMINATION** âœ“
- Severe violations: **IMMEDIATE TERMINATION, LEGAL ACTION** âœ“

**Examples of escalation**:
- Accessing colleague's email: Warning (first offense)
- Repeated after warning: Suspension (escalation)
- Stealing trade secrets: Termination + legal (severe)
- Hacking systems: Police involved (criminal)

## PART 3: INCIDENT RESPONSE PROCEDURES

### Incident Response Phases

**Phase 1 - Preparation/Detection**: **DETECTION, ANALYSIS, TRIAGE** âœ“
- Who detects: IDS alert, user report, log analysis
- Action: Verify incident occurred
- Example: "Unusual login from foreign IP detected"
- Tools: SIEM, IDS/IPS, monitoring

**Phase 2 - Containment**: **INVESTIGATE, STOP ATTACK** âœ“
- Containment: Isolate affected system
- Example: Unplug compromised server
- Investigation: Gather evidence (preserve logs)
- Example: Review logs, take memory dump
- Goal: Stop further damage

**Phase 3 - Eradication/Recovery**: **REMOVE MALWARE, RESTORE SYSTEMS** âœ“
- Eradicate: Remove attacker (patches, clean OS)
- Recover: Restore from clean backup
- Verify: Confirm systems operational
- Testing: Verify no backdoors remain

**Phase 4 - Post-Incident**: **LESSONS LEARNED, IMPROVE CONTROLS** âœ“
- Timeline: 1-2 weeks after incident
- Activity: Root cause analysis (why did this happen?)
- Output: Recommendations, updated procedures
- Follow-up: Implement preventive measures

### Incident Severity Classifications

**Critical** (CVSS 9-10):
- Definition: **SEVERE IMPACT, URGENT RESPONSE** ðŸ”´
- Examples: Data breach (100+ records), ransomware, network down
- Response time: **IMMEDIATE, <1 HOUR**
- Team: All hands, skip meeting protocol
- Escalation: CEO notified
- Example: "Ransomware encrypting all servers"

**High** (CVSS 7-8):
- Definition: **SIGNIFICANT IMPACT, QUICK RESPONSE** ðŸŸ 
- Examples: Malware on 10+ computers, DDoS attack
- Response time: **<4 HOURS**
- Team: Security + IT
- Escalation: Management notified
- Example: "Worm spreading to 50 computers"

**Medium** (CVSS 4-6):
- Definition: **MODERATE IMPACT**
- Examples: Single compromised account, phishing campaign
- Response time: **<24 HOURS**
- Team: Security department
- Escalation: Supervisor notified
- Example: "Employee's email account compromised"

**Low** (CVSS 0-3):
- Definition: **MINIMAL IMPACT** âœ“
- Examples: Failed login attempts, suspicious file deleted
- Response time: **<1 WEEK**
- Team: Junior analyst
- Escalation: Documented only
- Example: "Failed login attempts from single IP"

### Communication During Incident

**Incident response communication**:
- **External**: **WHEN, WHAT TO SAY** âœ“
- Legal: Regulatory reporting requirements (GDPR 72 hours, HIPAA 60 days)
- Customer: Transparency
- Media: Control narrative
- Employees: Internal notification

**Example**:
"We detected unauthorized access to 500 customer records.
Investigation ongoing. Password reset recommended.
Regulatory notification: 72 hours (GDPR)."

## PART 4: CHANGE MANAGEMENT

### Change Management Process

**Steps**:
1. Request: **DOCUMENT CHANGE NEEDED** âœ“
2. Assessment: **ANALYZE IMPACT, RISK** âœ“
3. Approval: **MANAGEMENT/SECURITY REVIEW** âœ“
4. Planning: **IMPLEMENTATION PLAN, TESTING** âœ“
5. Implementation: **DEPLOY, MONITOR** âœ“
6. Verification: **CONFIRM SUCCESS** âœ“
7. Documentation: **RECORD CHANGE** âœ“

**Benefits**:
- Control: Track all changes
- Reduce: Incidents from unauthorized changes
- Accountability: Who changed what, when
- Rollback: Can revert if problems

### Types of Changes

**Standard change**:
- Definition: **LOW-RISK, ROUTINE CHANGE** âœ“
- Example: Windows security update, firmware patch
- Approval: **IT LEAD CAN APPROVE**
- Testing: Minimal (already tested)
- Rollback: Simple (restore previous version)
- Examples: Anti-virus definitions, patches

**Significant change**:
- Definition: **MODERATE-RISK, IMPACTS PRODUCTION** âœ“
- Example: New firewall rule, database migration
- Approval: **SECURITY COMMITTEE REQUIRED**
- Testing: Required (test environment first)
- Rollback: Plan needed (may be complex)
- Examples: Major OS upgrades, network changes

**Emergency change**:
- Definition: **CRITICAL ISSUE, MUST FIX NOW** âœ“
- Example: Network outage, ransomware attack
- Approval: **INCIDENT COMMANDER APPROVES**
- Testing: Minimal (fix first, test later)
- Documentation: After the fact
- Rationale: Fix outage, document process later

### Change Scheduling

**Maintenance window**:
- Definition: **DESIGNATED TIME FOR CHANGES** âœ“
- Typical: Sunday 2-6 AM (low traffic)
- Notification: 2 weeks advance notice
- Backup: Before change made
- Testing: Before deployment
- Benefit: Minimize user impact

**Change freezes**:
- When: **HOLIDAYS, YEAR-END, CRITICAL PERIOD** âœ“
- Dates: Example: Dec 20 - Jan 2
- Exceptions: Emergency fixes only
- Reason: Minimize risk during busy times
- Benefits: Reduce incidents, easier support

## PART 6: COMPLIANCE & DOCUMENTATION

### Policy Documentation Requirements

**Every policy must include**:
- Purpose: **WHY THIS POLICY EXISTS** âœ“
- Scope: **WHO IT APPLIES TO** âœ“
- Owner: **WHO MAINTAINS POLICY** âœ“
- Review date: **WHEN NEXT REVIEWED** âœ“
- Approval: **WHO APPROVED IT** âœ“

**Storage**: **ACCESSIBLE, SEARCHABLE** âœ“
- Location: Policy management system

### Regulatory Compliance Mapping

**Scenario**: TechCorp handles customer payment data (PCI-DSS)

**Requirements**:

### Audit and Enforcement

**Audit types**:
- Compliance: **ARE WE FOLLOWING POLICIES?** âœ“
- Effectiveness: **ARE POLICIES WORKING?** âœ“
- Regular: **SCHEDULED, ROUTINE** âœ“
- Surprise: **RANDOM, UNANNOUNCED** âœ“

**Audit findings**:
- Non-compliance: **NOT FOLLOWING POLICY** âš ï¸
- Gap: Missing control or procedure

### Policy Review and Update

**When to review**:
- Scheduled: **ANNUALLY, EVERY 2 YEARS** âœ“
- Event-triggered: **AFTER INCIDENT, REGULATION CHANGE** âœ“
- Technology: New tools or systems
- Examples: New cloud service, remote work, AI

**Review process**:
- Owner: Policy author
